channel.title: HTML5 LightChaser
channel.description:
I need some testing done on this LightsOut clone I have been working on for anyone that had a shitty childhood and didn't experience the awesomeness of LightsOut you can read about it here http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lights_Out_%28game%29
Currently the game has a hard coded start level which requires only one move and then generates the next level randomly. However I have yet to beat a randomly generated level so can anyone confirm for me that they are indeed solvable I would appreciate it. You will know when you complete your level when a new one is generated. If you are really stuck (like I have been for the past 30 minutes you can hit f5 complete the first level again and start over)
http://silabsoft.org/lightchaser/
Source: https://github.com/silabsoft/LightChaser

item.title: HTML5 LightChaser
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

RSCShadow:

You don’t need to use jquery to show and hide elements, if that’s what you were implying. In fact, you don’t need to use jquery for anything. Also, you should look into using multiple canvases as layers. It’s a useful technique :).

I know I don’t “NEED” to use JQuery for showing and hiding the elements, but at the same time I would like to keep some sanity. also the multiple layers do you have an example to explain the usage of that? I guess I am just missing the point of having multiple drawing area’s unless it was to of course make draw coordinates more manageable.

Read full topic

item.title: HTML5 LightChaser
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

You don’t need to use jquery to show and hide elements, if that’s what you were implying. In fact, you don’t need to use jquery for anything. Also, you should look into using multiple canvases as layers. It’s a useful technique :).

Read full topic

item.title: HTML5 LightChaser
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

A few small bug fixes have been committed

New Updates:

  1. Added a small menu system, I know others use showing and hiding of DIV’s to do this and I had considered that but i do not want to be a total jquery whore and infact want to have the ability to remove all usage of it at some point.

  2. Added a restart level feature.

finally got the canvas offset situation fixed can now play on default page.

Read full topic

item.title: HTML5 LightChaser
item.dc:creator: @ollie123 Ollie123
item.description:
@ollie123 wrote:

[quote=“mopman_sucks, post:15, topic:441651”]following Gaussian elimination you would turn some lights from the top and then push them down row by row

Also some small bugs found when moving the game directly into a wordpress page:

  1. Mouse position was offset by canvas position however clicks are not. a fix for this will be released in the next github push.
  2. I use a poor implementation of loading resources need to find a better solution to that (Ideally i want to use JSON configuration for the entire game but have not played with jquery and json yet)

also as I stated above I moved the game directly into a wordpress page rather than my own html file it can now be played at: http://silabsoft.org/lightchaser/[/quote]

a901bbab5c0dee5c4981d1bd5606200e.png?1336855749722×176

EDIT: nvm, it works now.

Read full topic

item.title: HTML5 LightChaser
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

following Gaussian elimination you would turn some lights from the top and then push them down row by row

Also some small bugs found when moving the game directly into a wordpress page:

  1. Mouse position was offset by canvas position however clicks are not. a fix for this will be released in the next github push.
  2. I use a poor implementation of loading resources need to find a better solution to that (Ideally i want to use JSON configuration for the entire game but have not played with jquery and json yet)

also as I stated above I moved the game directly into a wordpress page rather than my own html file it can now be played at: http://silabsoft.org/lightchaser/

Read full topic

What is the best method to get rid of a single light? Anyone figure out a solution?

Read full topic

item.title: HTML5 LightChaser
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

Yes it is confirmed to generate impossible puzzles I do have Gaussian elimination implemented on generated puzzles now if it fails it will regenerate until it can produce a puzzle that’s actually solvable. I also have the option to switch to a 6x5 or 6x6 grid as any puzzle generated on a 6x5 6x6 is solvable.

I’ve uploaded yesterdays changes: it now only generates solveable puzzles thanks to: http://www.ueda.info.waseda.ac.jp/~n-kato/lightsout/index.html

added some basic text to make the game seem less boring:
http://silabsoft.org/lightchaser/

Now I really need a better level Identification system and some buttons and the game should be good to go.

Read full topic

item.title: HTML5 LightChaser
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

This really reminds me of a game I made a while back (unoriginal concept), except it had 3 colors it cycled through and had random shapes - either a 1, 2, or 3 block change, and also had an (almost always) anti-impossible generator :P. The bottom picture had to match the top. http://puu.sh/tITG

Despite how good your game is, I hate it because I had a lot of trouble finishing a single game. I think some of them are impossible.

Read full topic

item.title: HTML5 LightChaser
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

Your generator definitely generates impossible puzzles… I tried many times, with many different strategies, including linear algebra (failsafe) … :\

Read full topic

item.title: HTML5 LightChaser
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

it would be good to point out that the current version of random level generation is terrible as it does generate unsolvable puzzles. I will implement Gaussian elimination later to deal with this issue.

item.description:
@n-Development wrote:

Sounds really good. Ill be sure to keep up with the development. Finally a programmer that knows what she’s doing lol.

item.title: HTML5 LightChaser
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

[quote=“n-Development, post:7, topic:441651”]Pretty cool. I haven’t gotten into HTML5 too much. Maybe a few suggestions;

[ul]Add
[list][li]Time limit[/li]
[li]Lives[/li]
[li]Certain amount of moves[/li]
[li]Highscores[/li]
[/list][/quote]

Although I don’t really think this game could fit the usage of lives both timed and movelimit modes sound easy enough to implement, as for the high scores I am not really sure of an easy way to implement that unless i removed the random level generation and based it off of a set list.

Currently my goal is to somehow create a level id for the generated level so it can be sharable with the amount of moves the player took and then the friend can input that level id to play it.

The game is still in a very early stage so anything can happen.[/ul]

Read full topic

item.title: HTML5 LightChaser
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

interestingly enough that appears to be a different bug as the red light indicated the light is on and the grey light indicates the light is off. so the object is to remove all the red lights.

    function isLevelFinished(){
        for (var i = 0; i < lightSquared; i++){
            for (var j = 0; j < lightSquared; j++){
                if(lights[i][j].getState())
                    return false;
            }
        }    
        return true;
    }

try doing it the other way >.>

Rodgerwilco:

Show our “amount of moves” for high scores

that is planned but firstly I need to know to draw text on the canvas and I want some sort of level identification so others can share scores and levels.

Read full topic
